context.speaker: Ernest D. Grinnell, Jr.
context.text: First of all on grounds that the certificates had been inadvertently issued, they revoked it and issued in there instead new or amended certificates.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Grinnell, Jr.
context.text: Now they say we could issue these and then go into the Rock Island procedure and determine what condition should be attached, but we will do it all in one step here.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Grinnell, Jr.
context.text: So it seems to me that the first step is all that we are really -- that I am really concerned with right at this point, and that is that there was not sufficient evidence on those two facts alone to find that inadvertence existed because with those two isolated facts certainly it is permissible to infer that the certificates were inadvertently issued, but it is equally permissible to infer that they were intentionally -- that the omission was intentional.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Plus there's -- those are facts -- there is another very important factor one which Mr. Justice Harlan called the attention to, the assurance of the responsible body that it wasn't inadvertence.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But I'd like this to just carry on what Judge -- Justice Harlan asked you.

context.text: Don't you think that would be a good thing for Government rather than to -- rather than to be detriment and an injury to Government?

context.text: No, I -- I'd have --

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: The man was required to make a report to his superiors.

context.text: There, we think clearly in the case that it consistently held that there is an absence of immunity in that situation.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: We're dealing here, we think, with the case of a broader area, a discretionary officer who has a broad discretion for carrying out his duties of which we think includes the right to carry out and issue whatever press releases are necessary.

context.text: Mr. Friedman, I didn't quite -- no, I didn't at all understand your answer to Justice Harlan's question as to what the posture -- where we are in this case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Isn't that all they've decided?

context.text: But it hasn't done so and it's highly unlikely that it would do so and we certainly don't contend that here at all.

context.speaker: Walter T. Fisher
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.text: -- to the question of same offense apart from the subject matter that you and Mr. Justice Frankfurter were just discussing.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: And we say further in this particular respect that we're not arguing here with the right of the State to pass some safety legislation.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: We say that there is a place for state safety legislation but we say that the State can go too far in its attempt to state safety regulation and where it goes too far and burdens as Mr. Wines very agreeably concedes this does and then the state statute must fall.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: That's our position in this -- in this case exactly.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, I still have difficulty with the -- well, I consider the very penetrating question that Mr. Justice Brennan asked you, certainly there is a conflict between Arkansas and Illinois.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But -- I suppose nobody would suggest that this Court is qualified, there is all the conflict as to which has a better mudflap.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: We're not asking this Court to resolve that conflict.

Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc..speaker: Justice Frankfurter

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: But more than that in Maurer versus Hamilton, if that wasn't enough, and I think it was enough to point out in that case that here was a specific reservations of the State.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: In Maurer versus Hamilton, there was a very, very extensive record, an extensive record with respect to the need for that kind of safety in the State of Pennsylvania.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: There is no, no testimony in our case with respect to the need for this kind of contour mudflap within the State of Illinois.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I have -- I have Justice Black's curiosity of wanting to hear or see with my eyes the exact substantive power granted to the Commission which it could exercise tomorrow or next week and which it has withheld exercises as against Maurer against Hamilton where there was an expressed reservation to deal with this subject matter in the State.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I have the -- I have with me the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You probably have it in your mind, what is it?

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: This Court has held repeatedly that the reserve power of a State can be invalidated by the Commerce Clause, that the Clause is a bulwark of protection against the attempt on the part of the State to legislate with respect to burdening interstate commerce.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, that true but --

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: And --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- your answer to Mr. Justice Whittaker was that it never had interfered with the State in this field.

context.text: That is correct but because of the fact that there was nothing at the time when it did not do that that had any question of conflict.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: In other words, in 1952, when the Commission spoke on the subject, there was no question.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: That the sole issue was the right of the state legislature to act and that the state legislative act carried with it a presumption of validity.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: And they generally took the position that that was not involved because as a matter of fact, much of the testimony of the plaintiffs in the lower court was admitted.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: The basis of the interstate commerce interchanged operations and the like.

context.text: I'm turning to the question put to you by Justice Stewart yesterday.

context.text: If the State said that issue is not before the Court because if this is a safety measure and would be found to be a safety measure and it may be found to be a safety measure on the presumption that the legislation itself carries then why didn't they say that that is not an issue and therefore they ought to meeting the issues.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: I don't know why they did or didn't --

Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc..speaker: Justice Frankfurter

Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 31, 1959

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I mean isn't that the fact if -- if Illinois said, “That is not an issue before, Your Honors.”

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: At one point they were asked whether they weren't really suggesting that as to automobiles, the Southern Pacific case doesn't apply because railroads are different.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: We -- we ans --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And if that issue was not contested and if the issue which they did or goes against them, why doesn't Mr. Justice Stewart's question becomes pertinent in case we should disagree with the State namely that they then would have a right to canvass that issue.

context.speaker: David Axelrod
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You said yesterday, you thought not.

Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc..speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc..case_name: Bibb v. Navajo Freight Lines Inc.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You did but they didn't.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: They thought that they could rest on their claim that this is a safety measure justified or indicated by local police policy.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, whether rightly or wrongly, they didn't go into the other issue, they didn't so it appear.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And my question is what Justice Stewart's question yesterday was, are they therefore foretold from leading the issue if they choose?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In case one should agree with you and say, yes on this record there is ostensible or prima facie of undue burden.

context.speaker: David Axelrod

context.speaker: William M. Vance
context.text: And I thought over the lunch period what I would say to you and I do believe that this is it, that the rule making power is the Court itself and if they can make rules they can modify rules and I think in a hard situation where they were caught on the horns of a dilemma, the Court has the plenary power to say that although this is not customary with this Court, in this case we want to hear in this case and you can come in without paying this $20.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Alright now could they do that just as well if it wasn't a constitutional case, but --

context.speaker: William M. Vance
context.text: I think they could, I think it's within the plenary powers of the Court.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: To get back to Justice Black's question, how could a man avail himself of that, how could he get into court to have that determined by the Supreme Court if their clerk wouldn't file because he didn't have $20, that's --

context.speaker: William M. Vance
context.text: And the answer is that he couldn't, unless the Court through the communications between the clerk and the Court became aware that there was a crucial matter that they wanted to hear.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So then treat it as though they were form of certiorari.

context.speaker: William C. Mattison
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.text: Subsequent, this is the -- the pleading in issue, subsequent the plaintiff's pleading, subsequent thereto the defendant's agents, servants and employees fraudulently or unintentionally misstated to the plaintiff, but he had seven years within which to bring his action.

context.speaker: William C. Mattison
context.text: The Court has already started out from this appeal the fact that these misrepresentations of successive claim agents and so forth and statements which are contained in the petitioner's brief that examinations by doctors and so on that that, while it may certainly be true, is not before the Court.

context.text: The sole and exclusive pleading is the one which the Court has already latched onto on the argument, namely, paragraph 9 of the complaint.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William C. Mattison
context.text: Well, he might --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William C. Mattison

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.text: May I supplement what the question that Mr. Justice Frankfurter suggested to say that to me that probably another question something like steel seizure case.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Do you -- do you rest entirely here on the executive power to promulgate broad rules which have the effective law, determining who can and who cannot work for private employee without -- without any act of Congress?

context.speaker: George Cochran Doub
context.text: Well, Mr. Justice Black, I will turn to that.

context.speaker: John L. Murphy

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You can if the formal mandate is clear, one word.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Can it be modified by something that he said if there's an inconsistency -- there's an inconsistency remain?

context.speaker: Arno H. Denecke
context.text: Now, in this particular instance, there is no question but that Mr. Hahn, at the time of his injury and now -- and for one year after the termination of this lawsuit, in the event that the Court affirms the Oregon court will be eligible to receive compensation under the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Act.

context.speaker: Arno H. Denecke
context.text: He has a -- he has compensation and he always could have had compensation.

context.speaker: Arno H. Denecke
context.text: But relying upon the Davis case now, he has chosen to gamble and attempt to get a jury verdict which would substantially exceed the compensation which have him under the -- under the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, the question that Justice Stewart put earlier, what about the finding of navigable waters?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Would that be res judicata in a proceeding if you would have bring it under the Longshoremen's Act?

context.speaker: Arno H. Denecke
context.text: Well, I would think so, Your Honor, and -- and I realized that this is completely extra judicial here but I -- there's never been any question raised and -- but his eligibility for longshoremen's and harbor workers' compensation.

context.text: Sir, the language --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The only argument is let it go to the state courts, because I don't believe --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The argument is we don't know the merits of -- we can't tell the merits until the state court decides what the statutes mean, that's the argument.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That's the argument.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The difference Mr. Justice Frankfurter on the other hand is that in the meantime the irreparable injury is there which I would like to get to at this point.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Once the membership list is released and under this statute is made public, then the interference with the First Amendment rights recognized by this Court in the Alabama case immediately take effect as of the adoption of the statute, because this statute in the light of its purpose, in light of the record in this case, is in the same category as a self executing statute which this Court has uniformly struck down.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Such self executing statutes has appeared in the Pierce case, Pierce against the Sisters, and if it please the Court, the interesting thing about that case about going over to the state court.

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I think that the District -- the District Court took the position that they were so ambiguous and I think it's a judgment as between the two which the District Court made, which I think is very significant.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And that the Court did not just cast aside the abstention or judicial self restraint doctrine, they actually applied it.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: You see the language especially on 93, the instigation or suit or to whether the giving of money to needy litigants amounts to an inducement.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That language as I understand the opinion of the District Court is that the language in 35 has no possibility of ambiguity because it starts off, Mr. Justice Harlan, if you'll notice in the beginning the statutes are in the back of the appellant's brief.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: They start off with the definition in the very beginning on 35 and they run on and on and on, they took great pains to -- appears on appendix page 9.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I think that's the -- it's pretty hard to find ambiguity in Chapter 35.

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That language as I understand the opinion of the District Court is that the language in 35 has no possibility of ambiguity because it starts off, Mr. Justice Harlan, if you'll notice in the beginning the statutes are in the back of the appellant's brief.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: They start off with the definition in the very beginning on 35 and they run on and on and on, they took great pains to -- appears on appendix page 9.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I think that's the -- it's pretty hard to find ambiguity in Chapter 35.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Notice Mr. Justice Harlan on appendix page 10, all of the exemptions under there I think that helps to clarify it.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But that's the basis of the sending over the two statutes, and if I may with the permission of the Court, I'll state our position clearly on the points about sending them over to the state court.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the brief the appellants put it on two points.

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- judicial notice of the fact.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.text: Now, suppose I assumed that if this were referred to the Supreme Court of Virginia, it wouldn't invalid legislation that ought to be invalidated.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I -- because -- I wouldn't assume that Mr. Justice Frankfurter because I don't think ever get to that point.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I'm not arguing that point.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But if the -- if the meaning of legislation is referred -- if the other -- 31 and 32 are referred as 33 and 36 were for construction, unless you say there is nothing to Mr. Gravatt's argument, that the last clause of 31 maybe give him a construction that can withstand the constitution of the Act, and as of the sheer brutality, to refer to the state courts for construction, which no construction can save.

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The state court can say this.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, if it pleases the Court Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I -- I do not believe that this Court should go that far, because if the Court wants -- takes the position that there is -- although the Court cannot imagine it, and nobody else can imagine it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You must take that position and it's unimaginable that the Supreme Court of Virginia, the Supreme Court of Appeal of Virginia can cut the last clause 31 down to the proportions or to the meaning Mr. Gravatt has given us, namely that it should apply only to cases of designed inducing of violence.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, that we -- we have said to this opinion, I can't imagine a Court doing it, and my point Mr. Justice Frankfurter is --

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The state court can say this.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, if it pleases the Court Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I -- I do not believe that this Court should go that far, because if the Court wants -- takes the position that there is -- although the Court cannot imagine it, and nobody else can imagine it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You must take that position and it's unimaginable that the Supreme Court of Virginia, the Supreme Court of Appeal of Virginia can cut the last clause 31 down to the proportions or to the meaning Mr. Gravatt has given us, namely that it should apply only to cases of designed inducing of violence.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, that we -- we have said to this opinion, I can't imagine a Court doing it, and my point Mr. Justice Frankfurter is --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's (Inaudible)

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) for state authority, susceptible of any such limitation, that's what you're saying.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That's my position.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And -- and further Mr. Justice Frankfurter really that position adds up to this.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And it's more clearly set out throughout the brief than in the argument, that is that anytime a statute comes up, if it is -- hasn't been construed by a state court, the federal court should not touch it until it's construed.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But I don't have to take the -- I don't have to take an accepted position by counsel, in order to deny myself the right of taking a reasonable decision.

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well this one -- my position Mr. Justice Frankfurter is that this one clearly applies to the two appellees, the record shows it.

context.text: And the record also shows --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That is, it applies to your contention that it applies to those two appellees discriminatorily --

context.text: And they needed this type of statute to protect the railroads from trumped up litigation.

context.text: You have to have evidence in order to establish (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I don't see the -- any offer that's been made by the State that -- that requires this Court to excise its jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Marshall, on the question of equitable abstention, could you make clear to me, because it's not now clear, what prejudice to the appellees would ensue if the District Court should retain jurisdiction, pending a determination on a construction of an interpretation of these statutes by the courts of the Commonwealth of Virginia, in view of the fact that the District Court has already done that with respect to 33 and 36, what prejudice if any would follow if the same thing were done with 31, 32 and 35?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And also in view of what I understood Mr. Gravatt say and that is that pending a final determination by the state courts, there would be no proceedings would be initiated under any of this legislation.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, there -- there are two answers Mr. Justice Stewart, the first one is that under the Pierce and the other two cases I mentioned, Truax and Barrows, these self executing statutes, the injury starts whether you have enforcement or not.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, isn't that equally true of 33 and 36?

Harrison v. National Association for the.speaker: Justice Marshall
Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Harrison v. National Association for the.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1959

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I believe it's the peculiar business of the federal court to see to it that its doors are open.If a State passed a law preventing litigants from coming into a federal court there wouldn't be any question about it.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And these, the history and the statutes themselves when they say cases involving racial, what have you, it's obviously they are talking about the federal courts, there had been no cases in the state courts that I know of.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: There have been in the State Courts of Virginia, have they not?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The only one that I know of and recently in the state court of Virginia was the statute -- the case I mentioned to Mr. Justice Frankfurter that was not -- the Negroes didn't bring that case, the State of Virginia brought it for interpretation of the statute, some state office had brought it, we didn't.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The only cases that are in this record are federal court cases and if they can keep litigation out of the federal courts, they can maintain their massive resistance.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And that's why it seems to me that there is no reason for this Court to get to the point as to whether or not it should be sent over.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This -- this atmosphere down in Virginia, I don't think there is any question about it and I think that the real argument about the injury would be on that basis.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I understand.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Would you mind explaining what you meant by saying, that this Act that goes by it, can you absolutely preclude any operation of any kind by your organization or its lawyers in Virginia, what do you --

context.text: Well, Mr. Justice Black I -- I'd would like to go through two points, one the record shows and it was found that if the membership list is disclosed that the membership would drop off, I mean just it's not possible to determine how far it would drop off.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well a membership corporation cannot operate without members, insofar as the state is concerned.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: As to the actual helping out financially with the litigation the trouble there is that although possibly money could be raised, for example, the District of Columbia and around, to helping those cases, the statute prevents you from giving the money.

Harrison v. National Association for the.case_name: Harrison v. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We're in trouble if -- we now have the third Attorney General since this case started.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: First, we had Attorney General Almond, then we had Attorney General Patty, and now we've got Attorney General Harrison.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Now, if I understand, an agreement was many when Attorney General Almond was there, I assume that the others were on it.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But the -- the point if I may mention it Mr. Justice Black is that the members would be afraid to join even now for fear that at sometimes the statute might be declared constitutional to see membership, their name would be on the list whenever it was forced to be turned over.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: So they point out -- then was in connection with preserving the status quo along the lines suggested.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Does any Attorney General or interstate officer have the right or the power to say that he will forgive all past offenses under a statute which is held constitutional, which is under attack as being unconstitutional?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.text: Are you suggesting that if this were referred to the Virginia court, you and your associates couldn't participate in that argument or by brief?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So that on your point of view, I have no difficulty in saying there were 10, this unit of offense in the violence committed upon each one of the humans, but the problem of what the consequence is if you have a single impulsive act, it's a totally different part.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: Well, let's see.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Therefore, for practical purposes on this -- in this situation, although they did not concede that there was an error -- that they had violated the statute, 9 (b) (1), is it?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And you don't see --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Jonas Silver

context.speaker: Jonas Silver

context.speaker: Jonas Silver

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Surely, you couldn't see the law that in order for a State to obtain a person from another State that every State through which the docket might pass would sustain the extradition or the procurement of the person?

context.speaker: L. J. Cushman

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now on that premise, why would they not be binding upon the courts of Georgia in the situation that Justice Black put to you?

context.speaker: L. J. Cushman
context.text: For the same reason, I submit to you, that process issued by a court in Florida would be invalid and ineffectual to require a person to appear in another State -- in the court of another State for exactly the same reason.

context.text: What you say -- what you're saying is I presume that the full paid --

context.speaker: L. J. Cushman
context.text: [Laughs]

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: -- through the writ of habeas corpus and you'd say that that was not a valid order.

context.text: That's correct and --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: -- determine now whether this is a valid order all the way?

context.speaker: Reeves Bowen

context.speaker: Reeves Bowen
context.text: That it's utterly immaterial whether they put him before that grand jury that was in session in 1956 or whether they put him before a new -- new grand jury.

context.speaker: Reeves Bowen

context.text: That's right.

context.text: So the Section 3 (B) defined the category of the classes of taxable persons, and as I understand you in reply to Justice Whittaker when he finds out that the qualification under A the others not in country, not an issue out of a state trust and so on that that qualification is immaterial so long as you go up and see under A that is net income.

context.text: I believe that there may be provision in the statute for enlarging the bond if necessary in order to keep the injunction.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Specifically to pursue Justice Black's question.Should the County lose in this Court assuming the litigation that relied that could go on or rather if we cut that out because if it's allowed, it will not depend on my question, would you say the counsel for the County that is the petitioner should succeed in this Court and therefore, the judgment of your Supreme Court would set aside that it could on the basis -- it could invoke the bond to get the course of having gone to the Supreme -- having had to go to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin, and then having been allowed to come to the Supreme Court of the United States.

context.speaker: Donald J. Howe
context.text: To the best of my knowledge, that would be one of the provisions of the bond to cover such costs, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Therefore, the -- therefore, the money value of what is involved is still alive although everything else is closed up at the courthouse.

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: Well, I -- I'm not so sure that the bond itself was not required by Wisconsin statute to remain in effect pending the final appeal and determination of the matter, but further that under Wisconsin statute, even though through carelessness on either side, the bond has been permitted to expire, we were nevertheless if we prevail here, be permitted to -- to tax our cost and damages from the Circuit Court on through the Wisconsin Supreme Court.

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: So, that -- that's the point I'm sure would never be moved, and it also appears to me that if the Court is acting wholly without jurisdiction, as we believe this Court did, that there must be a way to get a pronouncement of this Court that such holding without jurisdiction action shall not be repeated in the future.

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: Otherwise, we would never get determinations in this Court on very vital public questions.

context.speaker: Carlton S. Dargusch, Sr.
context.text: And that was so only to September 30, 1955.

context.speaker: Carlton S. Dargusch, Sr.
context.text: Since that time, there's another statute on the books which treats residents and nonresidents alike with respect to storage.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Then what is your grievance here?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Your record as Mr. Justice Whittaker pointed, therefore, you come within the taxing power to the State.

context.speaker: Carlton S. Dargusch, Sr.
context.text: That is right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But there is an exception in the statute to nonresidents.
